para.text: The following Fishery Management Plans are adopted and incorporated by reference:
Chesapeake Bay Alosid Management Plan (July 1989), and Amendment I 1989 Chesapeake Bay Alosid Management Plan (June 1998);

Chesapeake Bay Blue Crab Management Plan (July 1989); Chesapeake Bay Blue Crab Management Plan (June 1997), Amendment I 1997 Chesapeake Bay Blue Crab Fishery Management Plan (October 2003), and Amendment #2 1997 Chesapeake Bay Blue Crab Fishery Management Plan May 31, 2012;
Maryland Chesapeake Bay Oyster Management Plan (May 2019) and Amendment 1 to the 2019 Maryland Chesapeake Bay Oyster Management Plan (December 2023);
Chesapeake Bay Striped Bass Management Plan (December 1989), and Amendment I 1998 Chesapeake Bay Striped Bass Fishery Management Plan (CB SBFMP) (1998);
Chesapeake Bay Bluefish Management Plan (December 1990), and Amendment I of the 1990 Chesapeake Bay Program Bluefish Fishery Management Plan (October 2003);
Chesapeake Bay Weakfish and Spotted Sea Trout Management Plan (December 1990), and 2003 Chesapeake Bay Program (CBP) Weakfish (Cynoscion regalis) Fishery Management Plan (FMP) (December 2003);
Chesapeake Bay Summer Flounder Management Plan (December 1991) and Amendment I Chesapeake Bay Summer Flounder Management Plan (1998);
Chesapeake Bay Atlantic Croaker and Spot Fishery Management Plan (December 1991);
Chesapeake Bay American Eel Fishery Management Plan (December 1991) and Amendment 1 to the 1991 Chesapeake Bay American Eel Fishery Management Plan;
Chesapeake Bay Black Drum Fishery Management Plan (September 1993);
Chesapeake Bay Red Drum Fishery Management Plan (September 1993);
Chesapeake Bay and Atlantic Coast Horseshoe Crab Fishery Management Plan (1994);
Chesapeake and Atlantic Coast King and Spanish Mackerel Fishery Management Plan (1994);
Chesapeake Bay and Atlantic Coast Black Sea Bass Fishery Management Plan (October 1996);
Chesapeake Bay and Atlantic Coast Tautog Fishery Management Plan (December 1998);
Coastal Bays Blue Crab Fishery Management Plan (September 2001);
Coastal Bays Hard Clam Fishery Management Plan (February 2002);
Maryland Tidewater Yellow Perch Fishery Management Plan (November 2002) and Amendment 1 to the 2002 Maryland Tidewater Yellow Perch Fishery Management Plan (December 2017);
Fishery Management Plan for Largemouth Bass (Micropterus salmoides) in Maryland Tidewater (January 2014); and
Fishery Management Plan for Tidewater Catfish (December 2021).

Under Natural Resources Article, §4-215, Annotated Code of Maryland, and a fishery management plan adopted in §A or B of this regulation, the Department has authority to substitute a regulation necessary to implement a plan for an otherwise applicable provision of Natural Resources Article, Title 4, Annotated Code of Maryland. In this subtitle, an intent to substitute an implementing regulation for a statutory provision is indicated by the phrase, "Notwithstanding Natural Resources Article, §4- . . . ".

Exemption from License Requirement. A buyer licensed by the Potomac River Fisheries Commission may buy seafood in Maryland without purchasing a Maryland license to buy, provided the seafood was caught in the Potomac River. In this regulation the term seafood includes finfish, crabs, lobsters, terrapin, oysters, hard-shell clams, and soft-shell clams.
Identification Number.

Unless otherwise required by this subtitle, all licensees shall display the identification number provided by the Department on every vessel, vehicle, gear, or place of business used to catch, hold, transport, process, sell, buy, or otherwise deal in seafood.
Display of Commercial Identification Number on Vessels and Vehicles.
The licensee’s commercial identification number shall be plain vertical block characters of not less than 3 inches in height and shall contrast with the color of the background.
All numbers shall be distinctly visible and legible.
Display on Vessels.
The licensee’s commercial identification number shall be painted or firmly attached to both sides of the vessel.
The number shall be positioned on or above the hull, forward, but not on or near the bow, and in such a manner as to be clearly visible to passing boats.
Display on Vehicle.
The licensee’s commercial identification number shall be painted or firmly attached to the vehicle.
The number shall be positioned on the front part of the body on the driver’s side.

section.heading: Violation of Regulations.
section.text: A person who violates any provision of these regulations is guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction, is subject to a penalty as set forth in Natural Resources Article, Title 4, Annotated Code of Maryland.

para.text: The Secretary may establish up to 3 free fishing days each calendar year.

During a free fishing day, a person may catch and possess finfish in the tidal and nontidal waters of the State for recreational purposes without an angler's license, Chesapeake Bay and coastal sport fishing license, or any fishing stamp normally required by the State, but shall otherwise observe all fishing laws and regulations.
The free fishing days are the first two Saturdays in June and July 4.

section.heading: Targets for the Number of Tidal Fish License Authorizations.

para.text: The targets for the number of tidal fish license authorizations issued by the Department are the number of authorizations issued between September 1, 1998, and March 31, 1999, including adjustments made annually according to specifications listed in §B of this regulation, listed by the following categories:

tr.td: Conch, Cancer Crab, Turtles, and Lobster Harvester

para.text: The targets for the number of tidal fish licenses may be modified based on:
Recommendations of the Tidal Fisheries Advisory Commission;
Recommendations of fishery management plans adopted by:
The Department;
The Chesapeake Bay Program;
The Atlantic States Marine Fisheries Commission;
The Mid-Atlantic Fisheries Management Council; or
Any other appropriate management body;
The number of individuals historically participating;
Target species, size, number, weight, incidental catch, total biomass, annual harvest, mortality rates, and other factors which are necessary and appropriate;
The number of license conversions made in accordance with Natural Resources Article, §4-701(m), Annotated Code of Maryland; and
The number of authorizations purchased back from license holders by the Department.

Except for authorizations relinquished for conversions made in accordance with Natural Resources Article, §4-701, Annotated Code of Maryland, authorizations that are revoked or voluntarily relinquished to the Department may be reallocated to individuals on the commercial license waiting list maintained by the Department.

section.heading: Dividing Lines of the Chesapeake Bay, Sounds, and Straits.

para.text: The boundaries set forth in §B of this regulation are designated as official dividing lines of the Chesapeake Bay, sounds, and straits.

Nontidal Angler’s License. A person shall be licensed in accordance with Natural Resources Article, §4-604, Annotated Code of Maryland, to fish in the nontidal waters of the State.
Chesapeake Bay and Coastal Sport Fishing License and Registration.

A person shall be licensed or registered in accordance with Natural Resources Article, §4-745, Annotated Code of Maryland, to fish for finfish in the Chesapeake Bay or its tidal tributaries up to tidal boundaries or in State waters of the Atlantic Ocean and the Atlantic coastal bays and tributaries.
Special Licenses.

Charter Boat License. The Department may issue a special charter boat license decal to an individual who pays the fee set forth in Natural Resources Article, §4-745, Annotated Code of Maryland, that is valid in tidal waters of the State for all individuals on a:
Single vessel operated by a fishing guide licensed in accordance with Natural Resources Article, §4-210.1 or 4-701, Annotated Code of Maryland; or
Vessel under the guidance of a fishing guide licensed in accordance with Natural Resources Article, §4-210, Annotated Code of Maryland.
Recreational Boat License.

The Department may issue a special Chesapeake Bay and coastal sport fishing license decal, which when permanently affixed to a boat registered in any state shall authorize any person on the boat to fish for finfish in the Chesapeake Bay or in its tributaries up to tidal boundaries or in State waters of the Atlantic Ocean and the Atlantic coastal bays and tributaries, to an individual who pays the fee set forth in Natural Resources Article, §4-745, Annotated Code of Maryland; and
The license decal may not be used on a boat that has been hired to take persons fishing.
License Decals. Except as provided in §B(4) of this regulation, a decal issued in place of a special license described in §B(2) of this regulation:
Shall be permanently affixed and displayed on either side of the forward half of the vessel for which issued;
Is not transferable;
Shall be color coded, dated, and of a size to be visible; and

Shall, when displayed, exempt all persons aboard the vessel for which the decal was issued or under the guidance of a licensed fishing guide from the requirement of possessing an individual license to fish recreationally.

Exemption for License Decals. If the license decal is not permanently affixed to the vessel, all persons aboard the vessel or under the guidance of a licensed fishing guide are exempt from the requirement of possessing an individual license to fish recreationally only if:
The individual who purchased the license decal is present on the vessel for which the decal was issued;
The individual who purchased the license decal is in possession of the proof of purchase issued by the Department; and
The license decal was purchased within the previous 10 calendar days.

Replacement Decals. If the decal issued in place of a Chesapeake Bay and coastal sport fishing license is lost or destroyed, the person to whom the decal was originally issued may apply for Replacement decal by submitting to the Department:
An application on a form required by the Department that includes a statement regarding the need for replacement; and
A fee of $5.

Registration. A person shall be registered in accordance with Natural Resources Article, §4-745, Annotated Code of Maryland prior to fishing in the following areas that do not require a fishing license:
A free fishing area described in §D of this regulation with hook and line;
On private real property bordering on tidal water as an owner or tenant of the property, or a spouse or an immediate family member who resides on the property with the owner or tenant; and
On a boat licensed as a recreational boat as described in §B(2)(b) of this regulation.
Possession of License or Registration.
The Chesapeake Bay and coastal sport fishing license or registration shall be in the possession of the person fishing and is not transferable.
In addition to possession of the Chesapeake Bay and coastal sport fishing license or registration, the person fishing shall also possess a separate form of identification.

Consolidated Senior Sport Fishing License. A Maryland resident in the calendar year in which they attain the age of 65 shall be licensed in accordance with Natural Resources Article, §4-216, Annotated Code of Maryland, to fish for finfish in the nontidal waters of the State, Chesapeake Bay and its tributaries, or in State waters of the Atlantic Ocean and the Atlantic coastal bays and tributaries.

Free Fishing Areas in Tidal Waters. An individual fishing in an area described in this section shall be registered in accordance with Natural Resources Article, §4-745, Annotated Code of Maryland, and is exempt from all other license fees and requirements.

Free Fishing Area in Nontidal Waters.
An individual fishing in the area described in this section is exempt from all license and stamp requirements.

A person who holds or is eligible to renew a license, registration, or permit, issued under Natural Resources Article, Title 4, Annotated Code of Maryland, or its implementing regulations shall update the person’s address of record within 30 days of any change.
Address updates shall be submitted in writing in the form and manner prescribed by the Department.

Unless updated, the address of record is the address a person provides to the Department when applying for or renewing a license, registration, or permit issued under Natural Resources Article, Title 4, Annotated Code of Maryland, or its implementing regulations.

section.heading: Dividing Lines; Tidal and Nontidal Waters.
section.text: The following boundaries are designated as official dividing lines for tidal and nontidal waters. These boundary lines are for the purpose of delineating those areas in which nontidal fishing licenses or Chesapeake Bay and coastal sport fishing licenses are required and tidal or nontidal fishing regulations apply, and have no other legal significance.

The Department may conduct pilot projects to demonstrate and evaluate new approaches to managing fisheries under the fishery management plans as incorporated by reference in Regulation .01 of this chapter for the following species:
Blue crabs;
Striped bass;
Oysters;
Hard clams;
Yellow perch;
Summer flounder;
Black sea bass;
Tautog;
Bluefish;
Weakfish and spotted sea trout;
Black drum;
Red drum;
Horseshoe crabs;
American eel;
Alosid;
Croaker and Spot; and
Catfish.

Pilot Project Activities. Notwithstanding Natural Resources, Title 4 (except for §4-1002), Annotated Code of Maryland, and COMAR 08.02, pilot projects may be conducted to implement conservation and management measures as defined by a fishery management plan.

The Department may select and designate certain persons licensed under Natural Resources Article, §4-701, Annotated Code of Maryland, to participate in a pilot project. A participating licensee shall:
Apply for a pilot program permit on forms provided by the Department;
Have a pilot program permit in order to participate in a pilot program;
Comply with any conditions of the permit; and
Be eliminated from the pilot project at the discretion of the Department.
The Department shall:
Develop pilot projects in cooperation with the commercial fishing industry;
Prepare a written evaluation of the pilot project to be included in the annual Fisheries Management Plan report to the General Assembly; and
Provide adequate notice of a pilot program through various media so that an interested individual has reasonable opportunity to be informed.
Species. The following species are defined as black bass:
Largemouth bass (Micropterus salmoides); and
Smallmouth bass (Micropterus dolomieu).

Unless exempted by the black bass tournament permit, all regulations pertaining to the harvest of black bass are in effect for black bass tournaments and can be found in COMAR 08.02.05.19 and 08.02.11.03—.04 and .06.
Black Bass Tournament Permit.
A person shall obtain a black bass tournament permit prior to conducting a fishing tournament that:
Has ten or more boats participating;
Has a specific location where fish are weighed, measured, counted, or otherwise entered into the tournament; and
Provides anglers an offer, reward, or incentive for catching black bass.
A person shall apply to the Department, on forms provided by the Department, a minimum of:
15 business days prior to the tournament if the tournament has ten to 49 boats entered; or
30 business days prior to the tournament if the tournament has 50 or more boats entered.
The black bass tournament permit may authorize more than one tournament provided the tournaments occur within the same calendar year.
Transfers of black bass tournament permits are not permitted.
The permittee or release boat operator shall be in possession of the black bass tournament permit while engaged in the fishing tournament activities specified on the permit.
A person with a valid black bass tournament permit shall follow all conditions on the permit.
Dead Fish Disposal. If fish die during the tournament the permittee shall dispose of the dead fish in accordance with the conditions specified on the black bass tournament permit.
Release Boats. A person operating a vessel used to distribute fish following a tournament shall comply with the conditions specified on the black bass tournament permit.
The Department may deny an application for a black bass tournament permit for failing to comply with the conditions of the applicant’s most recent black bass tournament permit.
General. A person may not use the following gear in the areas established in §B of this regulation:
Hydraulic clam dredge;
Bottom dredge; or
Shinnecock rake.
Submerged Aquatic Vegetation (SAV) Protection Zones.
Somerset County.

The fishery management areas of the State consist of the units in §§B and C of this regulation as delineated on maps filed in the Office of the Secretary of Natural Resources.
Fishery Management Propagation Areas.
The following areas are Fishery Management Propagation Areas:
Albert Powell Hatchery — Washington County;
Bear Creek Hatchery — Garrett County;
Lewistown Work Center — Frederick County;
Manning Hatchery — Charles County;
Piney Point Aquaculture Center — St. Mary’s County;
Unicorn Lake Hatchery — Queen Anne’s County;
Cushwa Hatchery — Washington County; and

North Branch of the Potomac River downstream of Jennings Randolph Reservoir and upstream of the overhead cable and red bank post located approximately 345 yards below the Jennings Randolph Reservoir spillway — Garrett County.
Public access to any Fishery Management Propagation Area is prohibited except with prior permission of the facility staff or as otherwise posted.
Fishery Management Public Fishing Areas.
The following areas are Fishery Management Public Fishing Areas:
Brownsville Pond — Washington County;
Brunswick Pond — Frederick County;
Bynum Run Pond — Harford County;
Evitts Creek Pond — Allegany County;
Forest Hill Lake — Harford County;
Frank Bentz Pond — Frederick County;
Hughesville Pond — Charles County;
North Branch Potomac River — Folly and Laurel Runs — Garrett County;
North Branch Potomac River — Gary A. Yoder Landing — Allegany County;
North Branch Potomac River — McCoole — Allegany County;
Rising Sun Pond — Cecil County;
Smithville Lake — Caroline County;
Unicorn Lake — Queen Anne’s County;
Urbana Lake — Frederick County;
Urieville Lake — Kent County; and
Wye Mills Lake — Queen Anne’s County.
Public access to any Fishery Management Public Fishing Area is allowed from the hours of 5:30 a.m. to 10 p.m.
Camping.
For the purpose of this regulation, “camping” means erecting tents or other shelters for the purpose of residing temporarily upon the property overnight.
A person may not camp on Fishery Management Public Fishing Areas except on designated sites or by written permit, or both.
Use of Vehicles.
For the purpose of this regulation, “vehicle” means a vehicle or vessel propelled by mechanical power that is capable of travelling on land, snow, or ice.

A person may not operate any vehicle on a Fishery Management Public Fishing Area without written permission of the Fisheries Service except on those roads, lanes, or areas which are open to automobile traffic or which are specifically marked by the Fisheries Service.
Feeding Wildlife.
In this section, “wildlife” has the meaning stated in Natural Resources Article, §10-101(cc), Annotated Code of Maryland.
Except for lawful fishing and hunting activities, a person may not feed wildlife in a Fishery Management Public Fishing Area.
Hunting and Trapping.
Hunting and trapping are only allowed in the areas described in §B of this regulation by written permission of the Fisheries Service.
Hunting is allowed in the following areas described in §C of this regulation:
North Branch Potomac River — Laurel and Folly Run; and
North Branch Potomac River — McCoole.
Urbana Lake.
Hunting is allowed only with archery equipment.
Firearms are prohibited.
Trapping is only allowed in the areas described in §C of this regulation by written permission of the Fisheries Service.
Projectile fishing gears, as described in COMAR 08.02.25.02 and .03, are prohibited in all Fishery Management Areas.

If the beginning or end point of a regulatory line is defined by coordinates and a physical description of a point or object on the shoreline, and the coordinates place the coordinated point in the water rather than on the shoreline, then the regulatory line shall be fixed to the location of the coordinates and be connected to the shoreline by the closest possible distance.

Except as provided in §E of this regulation, if the beginning or ending point of a regulatory line is defined by coordinates and no statement is made in the regulation about the physical description of the coordinated point, and the coordinates place the coordinated point in the water rather than on the shoreline, then the point on the regulatory line shall be fixed to the location of the coordinates and be connected to the shoreline by the closest possible distance.

If a point in a series of points between the beginning and ending points of a regulatory line is defined by coordinates and a physical description or location of the coordinated point, and the coordinates do not agree with the physical description or location, then the point on the regulatory line shall be fixed at the location of the coordinates.

If a point in a series of points between the beginning and ending points of a regulatory line is defined by coordinates and no statement is made in the regulation about the physical description of the coordinated point, then the point on the regulatory line shall be fixed at the location of the coordinates.

If the beginning point of a regulatory line that forms a closed polygon is defined by coordinates and no statement is made in the regulation about the physical description of the coordinated point, then the beginning point on the regulatory line shall be fixed at the location of the coordinates.

If the beginning or end point of a regulatory line is defined by coordinates and no statement is made in the regulation about the physical description of the coordinated point, and the coordinates place the coordinated point on land, then the point on the regulatory line shall be fixed at the location of the coordinates and be connected to the shoreline along the line or lines of direction to any preceding or following points in the regulation.

In accordance with Natural Resources Article, §4-212, Annotated Code of Maryland, a person shall obtain a scientific collection permit prior to collecting fish, fish eggs, shellfish, or aquatic invertebrates from the wild for scientific or educational purposes.
Application.
A person shall apply for a scientific collection permit on a form provided by the Department.
A person shall apply at least 45 days prior to when the activity is requested to begin.
The fee for a scientific collection permit is $10 and shall be submitted with the application.
A permittee shall:
Comply with all of the terms and conditions described on the permit; and
Report to the Department as specified by their permit.
Denial or Revocation of a Scientific Collection Permit.
In addition to any other penalty, failure to comply with the terms and conditions of the permit may result in the revocation of the current permit or the denial of a subsequent permit.

Prior to denying an application for a permit or revoking a current permit, the Department shall give the permittee notice of its intended action and an opportunity to appear at a hearing conducted in accordance with the contested case procedures set forth in State Government Article, Title 10, Subtitle 2, Annotated Code of Maryland, and COMAR 08.01.04.
Release of Finfish.

In accordance with Natural Resources Article, §§4-205.1, 4-11A-20, and 4-11A-21, Annotated Code of Maryland, and COMAR 08.02.11.04 and 08.02.14, a person shall obtain permission from the Department prior to releasing finfish into Maryland waters.
A person who is permitted by the Department to release finfish may obtain finfish from an out-of-State supplier only if the supplier is permitted in accordance with this regulation.
Prior to providing finfish from out-of-State to anyone in Maryland who plans to release the finfish into Maryland waters, a person shall:
Submit an application in accordance with §C of this regulation; and
Obtain an out-of-State supplier permit.
Application.
A person shall apply for an out-of-State supplier permit by submitting a completed application on a form provided by the Department.

A person shall submit required fish health testing documentation for viral, bacterial, protozoan, or parasitic infections so that the Department may determine if the finfish to be stocked in Maryland waters pose an unacceptable risk to native or naturalized aquatic resources.
Out-of-State Supplier Permit.
A permittee shall comply with all of the terms and conditions described on the permit.
The permit is valid during the calendar year of issuance.
There is no fee for the permit.
Denial or Revocation of an Out-of-State Supplier Permit.
The Department may deny issuance of an out-of-State supplier permit if the:
Applicant submits an incomplete or untruthful application; or
Department receives test results that indicate that the supplier’s stock may present an unacceptable health risk to native or naturalized aquatic resources.
In addition to any other penalty, failure to comply with the terms and conditions of the permit may result in the revocation of the current permit or the denial of a subsequent permit.

Prior to denying an application for a permit or revoking a current permit, the Department shall give the permittee notice of its intended action and an opportunity to appear at a hearing conducted in accordance with the contested case procedures set forth in State Government Article, Title 10, Subtitle 2, Annotated Code of Maryland, and COMAR 08.01.04.
